facts.text: Notice inviting tender contained detailed arbitration clause including clause 25 viii requiring 10% deposit-at-call for invoking arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: Contained in the numberice inviting tender is a detailed arbitration clause. In this matter, we are companycerned with clause 25 viii  which is set out as follows- viii. It shall be an essential term of this companytract that in order to avoid frivolous claims the party invoking arbitration shall specify the dispute based on facts and calculations stating the amount claimed under each claim and shall furnish a deposit-at-call for ten percent of the amount claimed, on a schedule bank in the name of the Arbitrator by his official designation who shall keep the amount in deposit till the announcement of the award.

facts.text: Appellant entered into similar contracts with respondent No. 2 containing the same arbitration clause.

facts.text: Appellant addressed letters to respondent No. 2 regarding appointment of arbitrator in those matters and sought waiver of 10% deposit fee.

anchor.surface_text: It had therefore addressed letters to respondent No. 2 with regard to appointment of arbitrator in those matters and sought for waiving the 10 deposit fee.

facts.text: Appellant received no response from respondent No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: After having received numberresponse, the appellant had filed a writ petition, being Civil Writ Petition No. 18917 of 2016, before the High Court of Punjab and Haryana.

facts.text: Clause 25 viii requires deposit of 10% of amount claimed before invoking arbitration, refund proportional to award, balance forfeited.

anchor.surface_text: viii. It shall be an essential term of this companytract that in order to avoid frivolous claims the party invoking arbitration shall specify the dispute based on facts and calculations stating the amount claimed under each claim and shall furnish a deposit-at-call for ten percent of the amount claimed, on a schedule bank in the name of the Arbitrator by his official designation who shall keep the amount in deposit till the announcement of the award. In the event of an award in favour of the claimant, the deposit shall be refunded to him in proportion to the amount awarded w.r.t the amount claimed and the balance, if any, shall be forfeited and paid to the other party.

holdings.text: The terms of an invitation to tender are not open to judicial scrutiny, as they are in the realm of contract, unless they are arbitrary, discriminatory, or actuated by malice.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that the terms of an invitation to tender are not open to judicial scrutiny, as they are in the realm of contract, unless they are arbitrary, discriminatory, or actuated by malice. Thus, in Directorate of Education v. Educomp Datamatics Ltd.,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Citing precedents like Tata Cellular and Directorate of Education, court applies principle of limited judicial review in contractual matters involving government tenders, allowing interference only for arbitrariness, discrimination, or malice.

holdings.text: The principle in Central Inland Water Transport Corpn. does not apply where both parties are businessmen and the contract is a commercial transaction.

anchor.surface_text: As has correctly been argued by learned counsel appearing on behalf of the respondents, this Court's judgment in Central Inland Water Transport Corpn. supra , which lays down that contracts of adhesion, i.e., contracts in which there is unequal bargaining power, between private persons and the State are liable to be set aside on the ground that they are unconscionable, does not apply where both parties are businessmen and the contract is a commercial transaction

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Central Inland as inapplicable to commercial contracts between businessmen and state, referencing para 89 of the judgment.

holdings.text: S.K. Jain v. State of Haryana is wholly distinguishable and does not apply to the facts of the present case.

anchor.surface_text: This being so, this judgment is wholly distinguishable and does not apply at all to the facts of the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause in S.K. Jain different in mechanism (tiered deposit adjusted against costs, full refund if no costs); no Art 14 plea raised there; here fixed 10% with proportional refund and forfeiture even on partial success.

holdings.text: Even within the contractual sphere, the requirement of Article 14 to act fairly, justly and reasonably by persons who are state authorities or instrumentalities continues.

anchor.surface_text: In ABL International Ltd.... even within the contractual sphere, the requirement of Article 14 to act fairly, justly and reasonably by persons who are state authorities or instrumentalities continues.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying ABL International, state instrumentalities bound by Art 14 fairness in contracts.

holdings.text: The aforesaid clause cannot be said to be discriminatory in that it applies equally to both respondent No. 2 and the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the learned counsel for the respondents that the aforesaid clause cannot be said to be discriminatory

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with respondents; clause applies equally to both parties, hence not discriminatory under Art 14.

holdings.text: Arbitrariness is a separate and distinct facet of Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: However, arbitrariness is a separate and distinct facet of Article 14. In A.L. Kalra v. The Project Equipment Corporation of India Limited

holdings.reasoning_summary: Citing A.L. Kalra and Maneka Gandhi, confirms arbitrariness violates Art 14 independently of discrimination.

holdings.text: Clause 25(viii) is arbitrary and violative of Article 14 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: We have thus to see whether clause 25 viii can be said to be arbitrary and violative of Article 14 of the Constitution of India. The first important thing to notice is that the 10 deposit-at- call of the amount claimed is in order to avoid frivolous claims by the party invoking arbitration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 10% deposit lacks nexus to frivolous claims (applies to all at threshold; exemplary costs suffice); disproportionate (forfeiture even on partial success); unfair/unjust; clogs arbitration process which is to be encouraged.

holdings.text: A frivolous claim can be dismissed with exemplary costs.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that a frivolous claim can be dismissed with exemplary costs. Thus, in Dnyandeo Sabaji Naik v. Pradnya Prakash Khadekar

holdings.reasoning_summary: Citing Dnyandeo Sabaji and General Motors, courts must impose exemplary costs to deter frivolous litigation; no need for pre-deposit.

holdings.text: Any requirement as to deposit would certainly amount to a clog on the arbitration process.

anchor.surface_text: Arbitration is considered to be an important alternative disputes redressal process which is to be encouraged because of high pendency... Any requirement as to deposit would certainly amount to a clog

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arbitration to be encouraged as speedy ADR; deposit greater than court fees acts as barrier; citing State of JK, Centrotrade, Varindera.
